pullRequest.body:
This is attempted 46478 times for `simp` and is successful 0 times.

---

GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they

nodes.body: !bench

### PR summary [5fb511416d](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15676/commits/5fb511416d806e4651dfd9afd82f1b6ae953c1c6)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

No declarations were harmed in the making of this PR! üêô
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

Here are the [benchmark results](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/run-detail/128ae669-99a0-4de9-9825-043f66f12f9a) for commit 6c29ce8e694fa5dd57fb28ae65f493d13ae907ca.
There were [no significant changes](http://speed.lean-fro.org/mathlib4/compare/c4a90627-4c39-4bc6-8a90-4f7fa9373c3e/to/128ae669-99a0-4de9-9825-043f66f12f9a) against commit 96a6efb931bacb29b366aa07146e1ac6a90b28d4.

General information: ```text lint: -9.6715 * 10‚Åπ (-0.138%) build: -68.003 * 10‚Åπ (-0.0552%) ``` 2 files got slower by at least 10‚Åπ instructions: ```text Mathlib.NumberTheory.RamificationInertia: +5.4142 * 10‚Åπ (+1.79%) Mathlib.Algebra.Exact: +4.4683 * 10‚Åπ (+2.99%) ``` No file got slower by at least 10%. 10 files got faster by at least 10‚Åπ instructions: ```text Mathlib.Algebra.Homology.DifferentialObject: -3.1134 * 10‚Åπ (-2.02%) Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Triangulated.Functor: -2.6756 * 10‚Åπ (-0.777%) Mathlib.GroupTheory.Coxeter.Matrix: -2.5101 * 10‚Åπ (-2.39%) Mathlib.Algebra.Homology.HomotopyCategory.SingleFunctors: -1.8658 * 10‚Åπ (-2.17%) Mathlib.AlgebraicTopology.SimplicialObject: -1.3443 * 10‚Åπ (-0.640%) Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Monoidal.Internal.Module: -1.2882 * 10‚Åπ (-0.730%) Mathlib.Topology.Sheaves.SheafCondition.OpensLeCover: -1.2523 * 10‚Åπ (-1.31%) Mathlib.LinearAlgebra.Multilinear.Basic: -1.2491 * 10‚Åπ (-0.842%) Mathlib.CategoryTheory.Idempotents.HomologicalComplex: -1.0946 * 10‚Åπ (-2.54%) Mathlib.RepresentationTheory.Action.Limits: -1.0013 * 10‚Åπ (-1.47%) ``` No file got faster by at least 10%.
There is a net positive, but it is a bit strange that two files got a bit slower. (Not sure if this is within the "noise" regime...)

Probably noise. Removing something rejiggers simp priorities slightly so maybe that flaps its wings and ... 

It is worth noting there are 100+ more of these non-applying simp theorems with more than 100 uses. Some have some pretty big type classes assumptions. I am interested to see the effect of bulk removal

> This is attempted 46478 times for `simp` and is successful 0 times.

The fact a lemma is never used by mathlib does not mean it is not a good simp lemma; we should consider downstream projects too.

That being said, this particular case is probably more in scope for norm_num. Can you add a test that norm_num can solve this, and a comment on the lemma explaining that it is not `simp` as `norm_num` can handle it?

I think that being attempted in rewrite almost 50000 times and failing every single time is the definition of a bad simp theorem. 

I'll check norm_num.

> I think that being attempted in rewrite almost 50000 times and failing every single time is the definition of a bad simp theorem.

I think the true blame here falls on `OfNat` not being used in DiscrTrees, but that requires a change in core.
A comment referencing the lean4 issue would be fine instead, if the `norm_num` comment is false.
The standard comment we use (on every lemma) is `-- See note [no_index around OfNat.ofNat]`

```suggestion
-- Note that the `no_index`es forced by leanprover/lean4#2867 make marking this `@[simp]` a performance hazard,
-- as it matches all equalities.
lemma ofNat_eq_ofNat {m n : ‚Ñï} [m.AtLeastTwo] [n.AtLeastTwo] :
```

pullRequest.title: perf(CharZero): de-simp `OfNat.ofNat_eq_ofNat`
